Before the blame game begins, have in mind that this has yet to pass Congress and is still a proposal as of yet. quote: ++http://www.foxnews.com/politics/first100days/2009/04/06/gates-calling-cuts-high-tech-weapons-programs/ WASHINGTON -- Defense Secretary Robert Gates is proposing deep cuts to some big weapons programs such as the F-22 fighter jet as the Pentagon takes a hard look at how it spends money. Gates announced a broad range of cuts Monday to weapons spending, saying he plans to cut programs ranging from a new helicopter for the president to ending production of the $140 billion F-22 fighter jet. The Army's modernization program would be scaled back, while a new satellite system and a search-and-rescue helicopter would be cut. Gates says his budget will "profoundly reform" the way the Pentagon buys weapons and does business. To fight new threats from insurgents, Gates is proposing more funding for special forces and other tools... This message has been edited. Last edited by: Canuck_Centaur, Thu 25 June 2009 10:18 PM

content: That is good. They are $140 million for each one past what is already ordered. The 187 we already ordered cost $361 million each, much of which was an R&D cost. They are a defense project that has gone overtime and over-budget. Something needs to clean up the way contractors run the DoD. Big contractors are rewarded for taking too long and spending too much. They know it takes so long for major projects that they can get away with whatever they want because the military wants the final product. Considering that at least three F-22s have already crashed it already has one of the worst safety records in the Air Force. There is no reason to buy more of them, they are merely a waste of our tax dollars.

content: That is good. They are $140 million for each one past what is already ordered. The 187 we already ordered cost $361 million each, much of which was an R&D cost. They are a defense project that has gone overtime and over-budget. Something needs to clean up the way contractors run the DoD. Big contractors are rewarded for taking too long and spending too much. They know it takes so long for major projects that they can get away with whatever they want because the military wants the final product. Considering that at least three F-22s have already crashed it already has one of the worst safety records in the Air Force. There is no reason to buy more of them, they are merely a waste of our tax dollars.

content: That is good. They are $140 million for each one past what is already ordered. The 187 we already ordered cost $361 million each, much of which was an R&D cost. They are a defense project that has gone overtime and over-budget. Something needs to clean up the way contractors run the DoD. Big contractors are rewarded for taking too long and spending too much. They know it takes so long for major projects that they can get away with whatever they want because the military wants the final product. Considering that at least three F-22s have already crashed it already has one of the worst safety records in the Air Force. There is no reason to buy more of them, they are merely a waste of our tax dollars.
